body: That is unfortunate but something that cannot be helped. The version information is stored in a class (`PHPUnit\Runner\Version`). This class can only be loaded after it has been established that PHPUnit is running on a supported version of PHP. Otherwise we might run into a syntax error as `PHPUnit\Runner\Version` could be using syntax not supported on the version of PHP trying to run PHPUnit.

Can the version information be moved into a non-PHP file and populated during the release build? Then the `--version` command can use this file instead of reading a PHP file which might not get parsed.
Good point. However, I am not comfortable introducing such a change in the `5.7` or `6.0` branches. Not yet, at least. I will need to think about this.
Such a change, if made, would also remove the need for this [hack](https://github.com/sebastianbergmann/phpunit/blob/master/build/version.php).

issue.title: PHPUnit's PHP version check error message doesn't contain the actual version
issue.body:
Steps to reproduce:
- Have PHP 5.5 installed
- Have phpunit 5.x installed
- Run `phpunit --version`

Expected outcome:

```
This version (5.1.3) of PHPUnit requires PHP 5.6; using the latest version of PHP is highly recommended.
```

Actual output:

```
This version of PHPUnit requires PHP 5.6; using the latest version of PHP is highly recommended.
```

Yes, I only had to `vi /usr/local/bin/phpunit` to see the version in the code, but I still think this could _easily_ be fixed to be an actually helpful message.
Plus, this is not special to the 4.x -> 5.x breaking change, it applies to all breaking changes.

body:
I did not feel comfortable with the approach shown in https://github.com/sebastianbergmann/phpunit/issues/2563#issuecomment-285728362 and have now implemented a solution for this that should work for the PHAR distribution of PHPUnit.

I understand that having multiple versions of PHP installed (I, for instance, have PHP 5.6, PHP 7.0, PHP 7.1, and PHP 7.2 installed on my machine) is not uncommon, but I do not want to add additional complexity to PHPUnit because of this. If you are able to install PHPUnit using Composer (which does check PHPUnit's compatibility with the version of PHP that is used to run `composer`) then you are on your own when you use different versions of PHP when you run `composer` and `phpunit`.

issue.body:
